Title.evidence: Background: ‘Downstream’ adverse outcomes associated with transfusion-related immune modulation (TRIM) occur postoperatively.

Trial_Design.evidence: The main aim of this retrospective observational study was to evaluate the cost implications associated with perioperative adverse outcomes following allogeneic blood transfusion (ABT).

Participants.evidence: Surgical patients (n = 2129) receiving blood transfusion at the Royal Brisbane and Women’s Hospital (Queensland, Australia) (2016–2018) were included: receiving ICS only (n = 115), allogeneic red blood cells (RBCs) only (n = 1944), or RBCs and ICS (n = 70).

Intervention.evidence: receiving ICS only (n = 115), allogeneic red blood cells (RBCs) only (n = 1944), or RBCs and ICS (n = 70).

Objective.evidence: The main aim of this retrospective observational study was to evaluate the cost implications associated with perioperative adverse outcomes following allogeneic blood transfusion (ABT).

Number_Analysed.evidence: Surgical patients (n = 2129) receiving blood transfusion at the Royal Brisbane and Women’s Hospital (Queensland, Australia) (2016–2018) were included: receiving ICS only (n = 115), allogeneic red blood cells (RBCs) only (n = 1944), or RBCs and ICS (n = 70).

Result_Outcome.evidence: Most adverse outcomes (≥3) occurred following RBCs and ICS (37.1%), followed by RBCs (23.7%) and ICS (16.5%).

Harms.evidence: Most adverse outcomes (≥3) occurred following RBCs and ICS (37.1%), followed by RBCs (23.7%) and ICS (16.5%).
